title: Noah Smithwick
text:
Noah Smithwick (January 01, 1808 - October 21, 1899) was a colonist who lived in <a href="Texas">Texas</a> from 1827 and until the Civil War began. A gun and blacksmith, he fought in the <a href="Texas%20Revolution">Texas Revolution</a> and served as a <a href="Texas%20Ranger%20Division">Texas Ranger</a>. Late in life he dictated his recollections of this early Texas period to his daughter, relaying colorful and humorous accounts, which included legendary Texans <a href="Stephen%20F.%20Austin">Stephen F. Austin</a>, <a href="James%20Bowie">James Bowie</a>, <a href="William%20B.%20Travis">William B. Travis</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson%20Rusk">Thomas Jefferson Rusk</a>, and <a href="Sam%20Houston">Sam Houston</a>, who he knew personally.
Smithwick was born and educated in North Carolina. He worked as blacksmith in Kentucky and in 1827 went to Texas and settled in <a href="San%20Felipe%2C%20Texas">San Felipe, Texas</a>. He applied for land in Stephen F. Austin's colony but never located it. In 1830 he helped a friend accused of murder escape. For this Smithwick was banished from Texas. After staying in East Texas and <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, he returned to Texas in 1835 at the beginning of the <a href="Texas%20Revolution">Texas Revolution</a> and took part in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Concepcion">Battle of Concepcion</a>.
In 1836 he joined a ranger company to defend the <a href="Bastrop%2C%20Texas">Bastrop</a> area from Indians, then went to <a href="Battle%20of%20San%20Jacinto">San Jacinto</a> arriving after the battle. He married Thurza N. Blakey in 1839 and settled in <a href="Webberville%2C%20Texas">Webber's Prairie</a> in <a href="Travis%20County">Travis County</a>. In 1850 he moved to <a href="Williamson%20County%2C%20Texas">Brushy Creek</a> in <a href="Williamson%20County%2C%20Texas">Williamson County</a>.
In 1849 Smithwick went to <a href="Fort%20Croghan">Fort Croghan</a> in <a href="Burnet%20County">Burnet County</a> and served as the fort's first armorer. In 1853 he bought and ran a nearby saw and grist mill. In 1857 he bought a mill and established <a href="Mormon%20Mill%2C%20Burnet%20County%2C%20Texas">Smithwick Mills</a> and a post office of that name was established. When Texas voted for secession, Smithwick was opposed. After receiving threats for his Unionist views in 1861, he moved to what is now <a href="Kern%20County">Kern County</a>, <a href="California">California</a>.
In his later years he lost his eyesight. Before his death in <a href="Santa%20Ana%2C%20California">Santa Ana, California</a>, he dictated accounts of Texas experiences to his daughter, Anna (Nanna) Smithwick Donaldson, which she published. The book, 'The Evolution of a State, or, Recollections of Old Texas Days' has been referenced in numerous books about Texas history.
